t: A Prayer of Moses the man of God.
Lord,*p thou hast been our dwelling place in all generations.
Before*p the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting, thou art God.
Thou*p turnest man to destruction; and sayest, Return, ye children of men.
For*p a thousand years in thy sight are but as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night.
Thou*p carriest them away as with a flood; they are as a sleep: in the morning they are like grass which groweth up.
In*p the morning it flourisheth, and groweth up; in the evening it is cut down, and withereth.
For*p we are consumed by thine anger, and by thy wrath are we troubled.
Thou*p hast set our iniquities before thee, our secret sins in the light of thy countenance.
For*p all our days are passed away in thy wrath: we spend our years as a tale that is told.
The*p days of our years are threescore years and ten; and if by reason of strength they be fourscore years, yet is their strength labour and sorrow; for it is soon cut off, and we fly away.
Who*p knoweth the power of thine anger? even according to thy fear, so is thy wrath.
So*p teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom.
Return,*p O Lord,*s how long? and let it repent thee concerning thy servants.
O*p satisfy us early with thy mercy; that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.
Make*p us glad according to the days wherein thou hast afflicted us, and the years wherein we have seen evil.
Let*p thy work appear unto thy servants, and thy glory unto their children.
And*p let the beauty of the Lord*s our God be upon us: and establish thou the work of our hands upon us; yea, the work of our hands establish thou it.
